   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:13.6/25.9/1.2, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:1084/11/0.09, ALT / AST:36/46, Alk Phos / T Bili:88/0.4,
   Differential-Neuts:95.8 %, Band:21.0 %, Lymph:2.1 %, Mono:1.8 %,
   Eos:0.2 %, Lactic Acid:3.0 mmol/L, Albumin:3.5 g/dL, LDH:224 IU/L,
   Ca++:7.9 mg/dL, Mg++:2.1 mg/dL, PO4:2.1 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 66 y/o man with PMH notable for type 2 DM, AVR X 2, and TBM
   s/p tracheal stent who presents status post PEA arrest.
   .
   # PEA arrest: Unclear circumstances surrounding the arrest. From family
   history, patient will fall asleep frequently during the day. This could
   be secondary to chronic hypercarbia which could be exacerbated by
   patient's multiple narcotic pain medications. Could hypothesize that
   patient took additional narcotics which depressed his already-tenuous
   respiratory drive leading to hypercarbia and hypoxia which led to PEA
   arrest. Other possibility is cardiac event but ekg on admit not
   necessarily concerning for MI. Other etiologies (electrolyte
   abnormalities, PE, hypothermia) less likely given lab and scan results.
   Unclear what type of neurologic deficits, if any, he will have
   following this event. We elected not to cool him per protocol with
   arctic sun due to length of time since arrest (~ 1315 and 1815 on
   arrival to MICU) in addition to instability of blood pressures (on 3
   pressors on arrival to MICU).
   - support respiratory failure as below
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - treat other issues as below
   - continually reassess neurologic status
   .
   # Shock: Patient's hypotension on arrival to [**Hospital1 19**] could be related to
   profound acidosis in setting of resuscitation or hypothermia. Following
   aggressive IVFs in ED, pressors were quickly weaned to off on arrival
   to the ICU. Could also be [**2-8**] to underlying infectious source (did have
   leukocytosis and bandemia on arrival) and most obvious source is
   infiltrates seen on chest CT. UA negative on arrival. Cardiac function
   (per echo performed in the ED) preserved at this time so less suspicion
   for cardiac shock.
   - continue to monitor blood pressure with arterial line
   - treat broadly for HCAP with cefepime / vancomycin
   - send sputum culture
   - repeat lactate
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Again unclear precipitant though patient has
   multiple pulmonary issues including sleep apnea (likely obesity
   hypoventilation syndrome), tracheobronchomalacia with recent tracheal
   stenting, and recurrent pneumonias (antibiotics almost continuously per
   wife due to sputum production). He also apparently takes multiple
   narcotics and other meds (i.e., flexeril, seroquel, valium) which could
   contribute to altered mental status which would exacerbate
   hypoventilation.
   - adjust ventilator settings per ABGs
   - obtain records from [**Location (un) 755**] regarding tracheal stenting
   - send sputum culture
   - add on urine legionella antigen
   .
   # Renal insufficiency: Unclear baseline creatinine. Would be helpful to
   obtain records from PCP or coverage over the weekend. Likely that
   creatinine will be higher in setting of shock and arrest, already
   improving with IVF and resuscitation.
   - trend creatinine
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - obtain records from PCP to establish recent Cr baseline
   .
   # CK elevation: Unlikely cardiac source given low MB and MBI. Troponin
   slightly elevated but in setting of renal insufficiency and stress from
   hypotension.
   - cycle CKs to peak
   - EKG in AM
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus: FSBS in 300s on arrival to the ICU. Will start
   insulin gtt and monitor blood sugars q1h until under better control.
   .
   # Hypertension: Hold antihypertensives for now given pressor
   requirement on arrival. Reconsider initiation of meds when stabilized,
   though home regimen unclear.
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia: Reinitiate statin when NG in place or patient
   taking POs.
   .
   # Chronic pain: Will continually reassess. Not currently on any
   sedation and will wait for mental status to improve prior to giving any
   narcotics or benzos, etc.
   .
   # FEN: npo for now as no NG, replete lytes prn
   .
   # PPx: ppi, bowel meds, pneumoboots for now (? heparin allergy)
   .
   # ACcess: R IJ CVL, right radial arterial line
   .
   # CODE: full, discussed with family
   .
   # COMM: with patient and family. Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 4273**] is HCP ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 4276**], Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4277**].
   .
   # DISP: icu care
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**])
 CARDIAC ARREST
   ICU Care

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old man with a complex medical history, including type 2 diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and tracheobronchomalacia with a recent tracheal stent. He was admitted to the ICU after a PEA arrest, which was likely related to hypercarbia and hypoxia due to his chronic respiratory failure, multiple narcotic pain medications, and potential sleep apnea.

The patient has multiple potential medical complications that require close monitoring and management:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has chronic respiratory failure due to sleep apnea, tracheobronchomalacia, and recurrent pneumonias. He requires close monitoring of his respiratory status, and adjustments to his ventilator settings are necessary to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest was likely related to hypercarbia and hypoxia, and it is essential to monitor his cardiac status closely to prevent further cardiac events.
3. Renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and it is crucial to monitor his renal function closely to prevent further deterioration.
4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is elevated, and it is essential to manage his hypertension carefully to prevent further complications.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose level is elevated, and it is crucial to manage his glycemic control closely to prevent further complications.
6. Chronic pain: The patient is at risk for chronic pain, and it is essential to reassess his pain management plan regularly to ensure that he is not experiencing undue pain or discomfort.
7. Infections: The patient has a history of recurrent pneumonias, and it is essential to monitor his respiratory status closely for signs of infection.

The patient's medical history and current condition make him at high risk for various medical complications, including:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's history of recurrent pneumonias and chronic respiratory failure make him at high risk for developing pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's history of recurrent infections and chronic illness make him at high risk for developing sepsis.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and cardiac arrest make him at high risk for developing cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Renal failure: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and elevated creatinine level make him at high risk for developing renal failure.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's history of diabetes and elevated blood glucose level make him at high risk for developing hypoglycemia.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his management plan as necessary to prevent these complications and ensure his safe and effective care.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing cardiac arrest. They were intubated and placed on invasive ventilation, and an arterial line and multi-lumen catheter were inserted. The patient received dopamine, levophed, and epi to support their blood pressure. They were also started on antibiotics, including vancomycin and cefipime.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.5°F, heart rate of 75 bpm, blood pressure of 121/73 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%. They are being ventilated with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and a PEEP of 10 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 24.5, hemoglobin of 12.4 g/dL, and platelet count of 231. Their troponin-T level is elevated at 0.09 ng/mL, indicating cardiac injury.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their altered mental status and respiratory failure. They are not able to move or respond to stimuli.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern, and they may require further management, such as increasing their tidal volume or adjusting their PEEP.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is a potential complication, and they may require further management, such as increasing their heart rate or blood pressure.
3. Infection: The patient's altered mental status and respiratory failure may increase their risk of infection, and they should be closely monitored for signs of sepsis.
4. Neurological damage: The patient's cardiac arrest and respiratory failure may have caused neurological damage, and they should be closely monitored for signs of neurological deterioration.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's cardiac arrest and respiratory failure may increase their risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, and they should be closely monitored for signs of bleeding.
6. Sepsis: The patient's altered mental status and respiratory failure may increase their risk of sepsis, and they should be closely monitored for signs of sepsis.
7. ARDS: The patient's respiratory failure may increase their risk of developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and they should be closely monitored for signs of ARDS.
8. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac arrest and respiratory failure may increase their risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias, and they should be closely monitored for signs of arrhythmias.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 66 y/o man with PMH notable for type 2 DM, AVR X 2, and TBM
   s/p tracheal stent who presents status post PEA arrest.
   .
   # PEA arrest: Unclear circumstances surrounding the arrest. From family
   history, patient will fall asleep frequently during the day. This could
   be secondary to chronic hypercarbia which could be exacerbated by
   patient's multiple narcotic pain medications. Could hypothesize that
   patient took additional narcotics which depressed his already-tenuous
   respiratory drive leading to hypercarbia and hypoxia which led to PEA
   arrest. Other possibility is cardiac event but ekg on admit not
   necessarily concerning for MI. Other etiologies (electrolyte
   abnormalities, PE, hypothermia) less likely given lab and scan results.
   Unclear what type of neurologic deficits, if any, he will have
   following this event. We elected not to cool him per protocol with
   arctic sun due to length of time since arrest (~ 1315 and 1815 on
   arrival to MICU) in addition to instability of blood pressures (on 3
   pressors on arrival to MICU).
   - support respiratory failure as below
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - treat other issues as below
   - continually reassess neurologic status
   .
   # Shock: Patient's hypotension on arrival to [**Hospital1 19**] could be related to
   profound acidosis in setting of resuscitation or hypothermia. Following
   aggressive IVFs in ED, pressors were quickly weaned to off on arrival
   to the ICU. Could also be [**2-8**] to underlying infectious source (did have
   leukocytosis and bandemia on arrival) and most obvious source is
   infiltrates seen on chest CT. UA negative on arrival. Cardiac function
   (per echo performed in the ED) preserved at this time so less suspicion
   for cardiac shock.
   - continue to monitor blood pressure with arterial line
   - treat broadly for HCAP with cefepime / vancomycin
   - send sputum culture
   - repeat lactate
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Again unclear precipitant though patient has
   multiple pulmonary issues including sleep apnea (likely obesity
   hypoventilation syndrome), tracheobronchomalacia with recent tracheal
   stenting, and recurrent pneumonias (antibiotics almost continuously per
   wife due to sputum production). He also apparently takes multiple
   narcotics and other meds (i.e., flexeril, seroquel, valium) which could
   contribute to altered mental status which would exacerbate
   hypoventilation.
   - adjust ventilator settings per ABGs
   - obtain records from [**Location (un) 755**] regarding tracheal stenting
   - send sputum culture
   - add on urine legionella antigen
   .
   # Renal insufficiency: Unclear baseline creatinine. Would be helpful to
   obtain records from PCP or coverage over the weekend. Likely that
   creatinine will be higher in setting of shock and arrest, already
   improving with IVF and resuscitation.
   - trend creatinine
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - obtain records from PCP to establish recent Cr baseline
   .
   # CK elevation: Unlikely cardiac source given low MB and MBI. Troponin
   slightly elevated but in setting of renal insufficiency and stress from
   hypotension.
   - cycle CKs to peak
   - EKG in AM
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus: FSBS in 300s on arrival to the ICU. Will start
   insulin gtt and monitor blood sugars q1h until under better control.
   .
   # Hypertension: Hold antihypertensives for now given pressor
   requirement on arrival. Reconsider initiation of meds when stabilized,
   though home regimen unclear.
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia: Reinitiate statin when NG in place or patient
   taking POs.
   .
   # Chronic pain: Will continually reassess. Not currently on any
   sedation and will wait for mental status to improve prior to giving any
   narcotics or benzos, etc.
   .
   # FEN: npo for now as no NG, replete lytes prn
   .
   # PPx: ppi, bowel meds, pneumoboots for now (? heparin allergy)
   .
   # ACcess: R IJ CVL, left radial arterial line
   .
   # CODE: full, discussed with family
   .
   # COMM: with patient and family. Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 4273**] is HCP ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 4276**], Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4277**].
   .
   # DISP: icu care

   patient's multiple narcotic pain medications. Could hypothesize that
   patient took additional narcotics which depressed his already-tenuous
   respiratory drive leading to hypercarbia and hypoxia which led to PEA
   arrest. Other possibility is cardiac event but ekg on admit not
   necessarily concerning for MI. Other etiologies (electrolyte
   abnormalities, PE, hypothermia) less likely given lab and scan results.
   Unclear what type of neurologic deficits, if any, he will have
   following this event. We elected not to cool him per protocol with
   arctic sun due to length of time since arrest (~ 1315 and 1815 on
   arrival to MICU) in addition to instability of blood pressures (on 3
   pressors on arrival to MICU).
   - support respiratory failure as below
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - treat other issues as below
   - continually reassess neurologic status
   .
   # Shock: Patient's hypotension on arrival to [**Hospital1 19**] could be related to
   profound acidosis in setting of resuscitation or hypothermia. Following
   aggressive IVFs in ED, pressors were quickly weaned to off on arrival
   to the ICU. Could also be [**2-8**] to underlying infectious source (did have
   leukocytosis and bandemia on arrival) and most obvious source is
   infiltrates seen on chest CT. UA negative on arrival. Cardiac function
   (per echo performed in the ED) preserved at this time so less suspicion
   for cardiac shock.
   - continue to monitor blood pressure with arterial line
   - treat broadly for HCAP with cefepime / vancomycin
   - send sputum culture
   - repeat lactate
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Again unclear precipitant though patient has
   multiple pulmonary issues including sleep apnea (likely obesity
   hypoventilation syndrome), tracheobronchomalacia with recent tracheal
   stenting, and recurrent pneumonias (antibiotics almost continuously per
   wife due to sputum production). He also apparently takes multiple
   narcotics and other meds (i.e., flexeril, seroquel, valium) which could
   contribute to altered mental status which would exacerbate
   hypoventilation.
   - adjust ventilator settings per ABGs
   - obtain records from [**Location (un) 755**] regarding tracheal stenting
   - send sputum culture
   - add on urine legionella antigen
   .
   # Renal insufficiency: Unclear baseline creatinine. Would be helpful to
   obtain records from PCP or coverage over the weekend. Likely that
   creatinine will be higher in setting of shock and arrest, already
   improving with IVF and resuscitation.
   - trend creatinine
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - obtain records from PCP to establish recent Cr baseline
   .
   # CK elevation: Unlikely cardiac source given low MB and MBI. Troponin
   slightly elevated but in setting of renal insufficiency and stress from
   hypotension.
   - cycle CKs to peak
   - EKG in AM
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus: FSBS in 300s on arrival to the ICU. Will start
   insulin gtt and monitor blood sugars q1h until under better control.
   .
   # Hypertension: Hold antihypertensives for now given pressor
   requirement on arrival. Reconsider initiation of meds when stabilized,
   though home regimen unclear.
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia: Reinitiate statin when NG in place or patient
   taking POs.
   .
   # Chronic pain: Will continually reassess. Not currently on any
   sedation and will wait for mental status to improve prior to giving any
   narcotics or benzos, etc.
   .
   # FEN: npo for now as no NG, replete lytes prn
   .
   # PPx: ppi, bowel meds, pneumoboots for now (? heparin allergy)
   .
   # ACcess: R IJ CVL, left radial arterial line
   .
   # CODE: full, discussed with family
   .
   # COMM: with patient and family. Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 4273**] is HCP ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 4276**], Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4277**].
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes, atrial valve replacement (AVR) twice, and tracheobronchomalacia (TBM) with a recent tracheal stent. He presented in the ICU after a PEA arrest, which was likely related to chronic hypercarbia and hypoxia due to his multiple narcotic pain medications.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: He is intubated and mechanically ventilated with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O, FiO2 of 50%, and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute.
* Cardiac arrest: He had a PEA arrest, but his cardiac function is preserved, and he is being supported with pressors.
* Renal insufficiency: His creatinine is elevated, and he is receiving IV fluids and resuscitation.
* Hyperglycemia: His blood sugar is elevated, and he is being treated with insulin.
* Hypertension: He is receiving pressors and antihypertensive medications are being held.
* Hypercholesterolemia: He is being treated with a statin.
* Chronic pain: He is being monitored for pain and is not currently receiving any sedation or analgesics.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 24.5
* Hct: 36.8
* Plt: 231
* Cr: 2.3
* TropT: 0.06
* TCO2: 25
* Glucose: 300s

The patient's physical examination shows:

* Intubated and sedated
* Pupils minimally reactive, sluggish, with a right pupil smaller than the left
* RRR, no appreciable murmur
* Rhonchi at bases, no wheezing
* Soft, obese, no tenderness to palpation
* Warm, trace peripheral edema
* No rashes
* Sedated, intubated, no corneal reflex, no gag, does not withdraw to pain in all 4 extremities

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure: He is at risk for further respiratory failure due to his chronic hypercarbia and hypoxia.
* Cardiac arrest: He is at risk for further cardiac arrest due to his underlying cardiac condition and the use of pressors.
* Renal insufficiency: He is at risk for further renal insufficiency due to his elevated creatinine and the use of nephrotoxic medications.
* Hyperglycemia: He is at risk for further hyperglycemia due to his elevated blood sugar and the use of insulin.
* Hypertension: He is at risk for further hypertension due to his underlying hypertension and the use of pressors.
* Hypercholesterolemia: He is at risk for further hypercholesterolemia due to his underlying hypercholesterolemia and the use of statins.
* Chronic pain: He is at risk for further chronic pain due to his underlying chronic pain and the use of analgesics.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Support respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and adjustment of ventilator settings.
* Cycle cardiac enzymes to rule out myocardial infarction.
* Treat underlying infections with antibiotics.
* Monitor blood sugar and adjust insulin therapy as needed.
* Monitor blood pressure and adjust antihypertensive medications as needed.
* Monitor creatinine and adjust medication dosing as needed.
* Monitor for signs of further cardiac arrest and take measures to prevent it.
* Monitor for signs of further respiratory failure and take measures to prevent it.
* Monitor for signs of further renal insufficiency and take measures to prevent it.
* Monitor for signs of further hyperglycemia and take measures to prevent it.
* Monitor for signs of further hypertension and take measures to prevent it.
* Monitor for signs of further hypercholesterolemia and take measures to prevent it.
* Monitor for signs of further chronic pain and take measures to prevent it.

Summary:

The patient is a 54-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of arterial line stop. The patient has a history of hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, altered mental status, and respiratory failure. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, with a respiratory support mode of CPAP/PSV, and has a RSBI of 92. The patient has been experiencing fluid overload, as evidenced by pink frothy sputum, and has required increased insulin doses due to steroid protocol. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 100.3°C, heart rate of 85 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 150/65 mmHg. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate dehydrogenase, and troponin-T, but normal renal function and electrolyte levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Fluid overload: The patient's production of pink frothy sputum and requirement for increased insulin doses suggest fluid overload. This can lead to respiratory distress, cardiac failure, and electrolyte imbalances.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's RSBI of 92 and requirement for mechanical ventilation indicate respiratory failure. This can lead to respiratory distress, pneumonia, and sepsis.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lactate dehydrogenase levels suggest potential sepsis. This can lead to organ dysfunction, including respiratory, cardiac, and renal failure.
4. Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and current cardiac status suggest potential cardiac complications, including arrhythmias, cardiac failure, and myocardial infarction.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's requirement for increased insulin doses suggests hyperglycemia. This can lead to ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome, and increased risk of infection.
6. Hypertension: The patient's history of hypertension and current blood pressure readings suggest potential hypertensive complications, including cardiac failure, stroke, and renal failure.
7. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status and lack of response to stimuli suggest potential neurological complications, including stroke, seizures, and encephalopathy.
8. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lactate dehydrogenase levels suggest potential infection. This can lead to sepsis, organ dysfunction, and increased risk of mortality.

   history, patient will fall asleep frequently during the day. This could
   be secondary to chronic hypercarbia which could be exacerbated by
   patient's multiple narcotic pain medications. Could hypothesize that
   patient took additional narcotics which depressed his already-tenuous
   respiratory drive leading to hypercarbia and hypoxia which led to PEA
   arrest. Other possibility is cardiac event but ekg on admit not
   necessarily concerning for MI. Other etiologies (electrolyte
   abnormalities, PE, hypothermia) less likely given lab and scan results.
   Unclear what type of neurologic deficits, if any, he will have
   following this event. We elected not to cool him per protocol with
   arctic sun due to length of time since arrest (~ 1315 and 1815 on
   arrival to MICU) in addition to instability of blood pressures (on 3
   pressors on arrival to MICU).
   - support respiratory failure as below
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - treat other issues as below
   - continually reassess neurologic status
   .
   # Shock: Patient's hypotension on arrival to [**Hospital1 19**] could be related to
   profound acidosis in setting of resuscitation or hypothermia. Following
   aggressive IVFs in ED, pressors were quickly weaned to off on arrival
   to the ICU. Could also be [**2-8**] to underlying infectious source (did have
   leukocytosis and bandemia on arrival) and most obvious source is
   infiltrates seen on chest CT. UA negative on arrival. Cardiac function
   (per echo performed in the ED) preserved at this time so less suspicion
   for cardiac shock.
   - continue to monitor blood pressure with arterial line
   - treat broadly for HCAP with cefepime / vancomycin
   - send sputum culture
   - repeat lactate
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Again unclear precipitant though patient has
   multiple pulmonary issues including sleep apnea (likely obesity
   hypoventilation syndrome), tracheobronchomalacia with recent tracheal
   stenting, and recurrent pneumonias (antibiotics almost continuously per
   wife due to sputum production). He also apparently takes multiple
   narcotics and other meds (i.e., flexeril, seroquel, valium) which could
   contribute to altered mental status which would exacerbate
   hypoventilation.
   - adjust ventilator settings per ABGs
   - obtain records from [**Location (un) 755**] regarding tracheal stenting
   - send sputum culture
   - add on urine legionella antigen
   .
   # Renal insufficiency: Unclear baseline creatinine. Would be helpful to
   obtain records from PCP or coverage over the weekend. Likely that
   creatinine will be higher in setting of shock and arrest, already
   improving with IVF and resuscitation.
   - trend creatinine
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - obtain records from PCP to establish recent Cr baseline
   .
   # CK elevation: Unlikely cardiac source given low MB and MBI. Troponin
   slightly elevated but in setting of renal insufficiency and stress from
   hypotension.
   - cycle CKs to peak
   - EKG in AM
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus: FSBS in 300s on arrival to the ICU. Will start
   insulin gtt and monitor blood sugars q1h until under better control.
   .
   # Hypertension: Hold antihypertensives for now given pressor
   requirement on arrival. Reconsider initiation of meds when stabilized,
   though home regimen unclear.
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia: Reinitiate statin when NG in place or patient
   taking POs.
   .
   # Chronic pain: Will continually reassess. Not currently on any
   sedation and will wait for mental status to improve prior to giving any
   narcotics or benzos, etc.
   .
   # FEN: npo for now as no NG, replete lytes prn
   .
   # PPx: ppi, bowel meds, pneumoboots for now (? heparin allergy)
   .
   # ACcess: R IJ CVL, right radial arterial line
   .
   # CODE: full, discussed with family
   .
   # COMM: with patient and family. Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 4273**] is HCP ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 4276**], Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4277**].
   .

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition and potential medical complications as follows:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 66-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes, atrial valve replacement, and tuberculous meningitis, who presented with a status post PEA arrest.
* He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation.
* His blood pressure is unstable, requiring pressors, and he has a history of shock.
* He has a fever spike to 100.3°F, and blood cultures have been sent.
* His electrolyte levels are abnormal, with a low potassium level of 3.5 mEq/L and a high magnesium level of 2.2 mg/dL.
* He has a high creatinine level of 2.4 mg/dL, indicating renal insufficiency.
* His CK level is elevated, but the source is unclear.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he requires mechanical ventilation. He has a history of sleep apnea, tracheobronchomalacia, and recurrent pneumonias, which may contribute to his respiratory failure.
* Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of atrial valve replacement and a recent PEA arrest, which may indicate cardiac instability.
* Renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, indicating renal insufficiency. This may be due to shock, hypotension, or underlying kidney disease.
* Infection: The patient has a fever spike and blood cultures have been sent, indicating the possibility of infection.
* Fluid overload: The patient's fluid balance is abnormal, with a net fluid loss of -1,101 mL, which may indicate fluid overload.
* Hypertension: The patient has a history of hypertension and is currently receiving pressors, which may increase his blood pressure.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient has a history of diabetes and is currently receiving insulin, which may be necessary to control his blood sugar levels.
* Neurologic complications: The patient has a history of altered mental status, which may be due to his underlying medical conditions, medications, or hypoxia.
* Other complications: The patient has a history of chronic pain, which may require ongoing management. He also has a history of hypercholesterolemia, which may require treatment.

**Assessment and Plan:**

* Support respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
* Cycle cardiac enzymes to monitor for cardiac complications.
* Treat shock with pressors and fluids as needed.
* Monitor blood pressure and electrolyte levels closely.
* Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust medications as needed.
* Send sputum cultures and urine legionella antigen to rule out infection.
* Continue to reassess the patient's neurologic status and adjust treatment as needed.
* Monitor the patient's glycemic control and adjust insulin therapy as needed.
* Consider initiating antihypertensive medications when the patient is stabilized.
* Continue to monitor the patient's fluid balance and adjust fluid management as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old man with a complex medical history, including type 2 diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and tracheobronchomalacia. He presents with respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, and shock. The note highlights several potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, with a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 262. He requires mechanical ventilation and has a risk of developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient had a cardiac arrest, which was likely related to his underlying medical conditions. He is currently on pressors and has a risk of developing cardiac shock.
3. Shock: The patient's hypotension on arrival to the ICU could be related to profound acidosis, hypothermia, or an underlying infectious source. He is at risk of developing further hypotension and organ dysfunction.
4. Renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he has a risk of developing acute kidney injury (AKI).
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels are elevated, and he is at risk of developing diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA).
6. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is elevated, and he is at risk of developing hypertensive emergency.
7. Infection: The patient has a risk of developing a nosocomial infection, particularly pneumonia, given his underlying respiratory conditions and recent intubation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. ARDS
2. Cardiac shock
3. AKI
4. DKA
5. Hypertensive emergency
6. Nosocomial pneumonia
7. Sepsis
8. Multi-organ failure

The patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiac, and metabolic status to prevent these complications and improve his outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old man with a complex medical history, including type 2 diabetes, atrial valve replacement, and tracheobronchomalacia with a recent tracheal stent. He presented to the hospital in cardiac arrest and was intubated and sedated.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient has multiple pulmonary issues, including sleep apnea, tracheobronchomalacia, and recurrent pneumonias, which may contribute to his respiratory failure. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and is being weaned off the ventilator.
* Renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he has been treated with IV fluids and diuretics. His renal function is improving.
* Cardiac status: The patient had a cardiac arrest, but his cardiac function is preserved. He is being treated with antihypertensives and is being monitored for cardiac complications.
* Shock: The patient's hypotension on arrival to the hospital may have been related to profound acidosis, hypothermia, or an underlying infectious source. He is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and is being monitored for signs of shock.
* CK elevation: The patient's CK level is elevated, but it is unlikely to be related to a cardiac source. He is being monitored for signs of muscle damage.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen if he does not respond to treatment or if he develops an underlying infection.
* Renal insufficiency: The patient's renal function can worsen if he does not respond to treatment or if he develops an underlying infection.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status can worsen if he develops an underlying cardiac condition, such as a myocardial infarction or cardiac tamponade.
* Shock: The patient's shock can worsen if he does not respond to treatment or if he develops an underlying infection.
* Infection: The patient is at risk for developing an underlying infection, particularly pneumonia, given his tracheobronchomalacia and recent tracheal stent.
* Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure can worsen if he does not respond to treatment or if he develops an underlying infection.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Respiratory support: The patient is being weaned off the ventilator and is being monitored for signs of respiratory failure.
* Renal support: The patient is being treated with IV fluids and diuretics to improve his renal function.
* Cardiac support: The patient is being treated with antihypertensives and is being monitored for signs of cardiac complications.
* Antibiotic therapy: The patient is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover potential infections.
* Monitoring: The patient is being closely monitored for signs of respiratory failure, renal insufficiency, cardiac complications, shock, and infection.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical issues, and his treatment plan requires careful monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 66-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and tracheobronchomalacia with a recent tracheal stent. He presents with respiratory failure, renal insufficiency, cardiac arrest, and shock. His respiratory failure is likely due to multiple pulmonary issues, including sleep apnea, tracheobronchomalacia, and recurrent pneumonias. His cardiac arrest is unclear, but it may be related to chronic hypercarbia, hypoxia, or an electrolyte abnormality.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 20.0
* Hct: 33.4
* Plt: 183
* Cr: 2.2
* TropT: 0.07
* CK: 1109
* ALT: 36
* AST: 46
* Alk Phos: 88
* T Bili: 0.4
* LDH: 224 IU/L
* Ca++: 8.3 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.3 mg/dL
* PO4: 2.8 mg/dL

The patient is currently receiving the following medications:

* Propofol
* Pantoprazole
* Metoprolol
* Hydralazine
* Furosemide
* Lantus

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning from ventilator and extubation on December 22
* Trending creatinine and adjusting medications accordingly
* Avoiding nephrotoxins
* Obtaining records from PCP to establish recent Cr baseline
* Continuing to monitor blood pressure with arterial line
* Treating broadly for HCAP with cefepime and vancomycin
* Sending sputum culture
* Repeating lactate
* Cycling CKs to peak
* EKG in the morning

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Prolonged mechanical ventilation, respiratory acidosis, and hypoxemia.
* Renal insufficiency: Acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and electrolyte imbalances.
* Cardiac arrest: Re-arrest, cardiac arrhythmias, and cardiac failure.
* Shock: Hypotension, organ dysfunction, and death.
* Hyperglycemia: Diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome, and hypoglycemia.
* Hypertension: Cardiac failure, hypertensive crisis, and cerebral edema.
* Hypercholesterolemia: Atherosclerosis, coronary artery disease, and stroke.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and tracheobronchomalacia with a recent tracheal stent. He presented to the ICU with respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, and renal insufficiency. 

The patient has been receiving multiple antibiotics, including vancomycin and cefepime, for suspected hospital-acquired pneumonia. He is also receiving propofol for sedation and has been weaned off pressors. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with an SpO2 of 97% on 40% FiO2. His ventilator settings are being adjusted based on his ABGs. 

The patient's cardiac status is being monitored, and he is being treated for possible cardiac shock. His cardiac enzymes are being cycled, and his electrocardiogram (EKG) is being monitored. His blood pressure is stable, and he is no longer on pressors. 

The patient's renal function is improving, and his creatinine is trending downward. His blood sugar is being monitored, and he is receiving insulin therapy. His hypertension is being managed with medication, and his hypercholesterolemia is being treated with a statin. 

The patient's chronic pain is being monitored, and he is not currently receiving any sedation or analgesics. His shock is being treated with aggressive fluid resuscitation and antibiotics. His chest CT shows infiltrates, which are a possible source of his infection. 

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he is still receiving ventilator support. Weaning him off the ventilator will be crucial to prevent prolonged mechanical ventilation and its associated complications.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is being monitored, and he is being treated for possible cardiac shock. Continued monitoring of his cardiac enzymes and EKG will be necessary to detect any potential cardiac complications.
3. Renal complications: The patient's renal function is improving, but continued monitoring of his creatinine and electrolyte levels will be necessary to detect any potential renal complications.
4. Infection: The patient is at risk for developing a secondary infection, particularly given his prolonged hospital stay and multiple antibiotics.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient is receiving insulin therapy, and hypoglycemia is a potential complication.
6. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is stable, but continued monitoring will be necessary to detect any potential hypotensive episodes.
7. Neurologic complications: The patient's neurologic status is being monitored, and he is at risk for developing neurologic complications, particularly given his prolonged hospital stay and multiple medications.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, but continued close monitoring and management will be necessary to prevent potential complications and ensure his optimal recovery.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a complex medical history, including hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, altered mental status, acute respiratory failure, and cardiac arrest. The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and has a tracheostomy in place. They have a history of cardiac arrest and are currently being monitored for any signs of cardiac instability.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 80 beats per minute, blood pressure of 136/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97%. They are receiving propofol and metoprolol infusions, as well as insulin and furosemide. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute and a tidal volume of 408 milliliters.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of acute kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 1.4 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen level of 29 mg/dL. They also have evidence of liver dysfunction, with an aspartate aminotransferase level of 46 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase level of 36 IU/L.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac instability: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and is currently receiving medications that may affect cardiac function, such as metoprolol and furosemide. Close monitoring of cardiac rhythms and hemodynamics is necessary to prevent cardiac instability.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, but their respiratory status is still unstable. Close monitoring of respiratory function and adjustments to ventilation settings as needed are necessary to prevent respiratory failure.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, indicating acute kidney injury. Close monitoring of renal function and adjustments to medications and fluids as needed are necessary to prevent further kidney injury.
4. Liver dysfunction: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, indicating liver dysfunction. Close monitoring of liver function and adjustments to medications and fluids as needed are necessary to prevent further liver dysfunction.
5. Sepsis: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and is receiving antibiotics, which may increase the risk of sepsis. Close monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of sepsis early.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of their complex medical condition to prevent further complications and improve their chances of recovery.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 66 y/o man with PMH notable for type 2 DM, AVR X 2, and TBM
   s/p tracheal stent who presents status post PEA arrest.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Again unclear precipitant though patient has
   multiple pulmonary issues including sleep apnea (likely obesity
   hypoventilation syndrome), tracheobronchomalacia with recent tracheal
   stenting, and recurrent pneumonias (antibiotics almost continuously per
   wife due to sputum production). He also apparently takes multiple
   narcotics and other meds (i.e., flexeril, seroquel, valium) which could
   contribute to altered mental status which would exacerbate
   hypoventilation.
   - adjust ventilator settings per ABGs
 currently on PSV wean, on vent
   overnight - > diuresed overnight and this AM
 extubated on [**12-23**]
   - obtained records from [**Location (un) 755**] regarding tracheal stenting
   - send sputum culture
 if available
 Coag + SA
 cover with
   Vanc/Cefepime until [**Last Name (un) 4361**]
   - urine legionella antigen - negative
   .
   # Renal insufficiency: Unclear baseline creatinine. Would be helpful to
   obtain records from PCP or coverage over the weekend. Likely that
   creatinine will be higher in setting of shock and arrest, already
   improving with IVF and resuscitation.
   - trend creatinine
 improving as of [**12-23**]
   - adjusted meds for improved renal fxn
   - avoided nephrotoxins
   - obtained recs from [**Hospital3 3928**]
 renal fxn baseline ~ 0.9-1.1.
   .
   # Cardiac status: Unclear circumstances surrounding the arrest. From
   family history, patient will fall asleep frequently during the day.
   This could be secondary to chronic hypercarbia which could be
   exacerbated by patient's multiple narcotic pain medications. Could
   hypothesize that patient took additional narcotics which depressed his
   already-tenuous respiratory drive leading to hypercarbia and hypoxia
   which led to PEA arrest. Other possibility is cardiac event but ekg on
   admit not necessarily concerning for MI. Other etiologies (electrolyte
   abnormalities, PE, hypothermia) less likely given lab and scan results.
   Unclear what type of neurologic deficits, if any, he will have
   following this event. We elected not to cool him per protocol with
   arctic sun due to length of time since arrest (~ 1315 and 1815 on
   arrival to MICU) in addition to instability of blood pressures (on 3
   pressors on arrival to MICU).
   - off pressors
   - overnight and this AM pt had continuous firing of pacer
 EP will
   re-eval [**12-23**]
   - support respiratory failure
 now extubated on face tent
   - enzymes cycled
 no issues remain
   - reassess neurologic status now that pt is extubated
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus: FSBS in 300s on arrival to the ICU. Will start
   insulin gtt and monitor blood sugars q1h until under better control.
 advanced Lantus to 20 [**Hospital1 7**], will start on home regimen when back to
   eating will follow FSBGs
   .
   # Hypertension: Hold antihypertensives for now given pressor
   requirement on arrival. Reconsider initiation of meds when stabilized,
   though home regimen unclear.  Stabilized started BP medications
   - started correction to previous note - started Metoprolol and Hydral
   [**12-20**]
   - once PO plan is to restart home meds
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia: Reinitiate statin when NG in place or patient
   taking POs.
   .
   # Chronic pain: Will continually reassess. D/c
d sedation and will wait
   for mental status to improve prior to giving any narcotics or benzos,
   etc.
   .
   . # Shock: Patient's hypotension on arrival to [**Hospital1 19**] could be related
   to profound acidosis in setting of resuscitation or hypothermia.
   Following aggressive IVFs in ED, pressors were quickly weaned to off on
   arrival to the ICU. Could also be [**2-8**] to underlying infectious source
   (did have leukocytosis and bandemia on arrival) and most obvious source
   is infiltrates seen on chest CT. UA negative on arrival. Cardiac
   function (per echo performed in the ED) preserved at this time so less
   suspicion for cardiac shock. Resolved
   - continue to monitor blood pressure with arterial line
   - treat broadly for HCAP with cefepime / vancomycin
   - send sputum culture
   - repeat lactate
   - pressures stable
   .
   # CK elevation: Unlikely cardiac source given low MB and MBI. Troponin
   slightly elevated but in setting of renal insufficiency and stress from
   hypotension.  Resolved
   - cycle CKs to peak
   - EKG in AM
   .
   # FEN: npo for now as no NG, replete lytes prn
   .
   # PPx: ppi, bowel meds, pneumoboots for now
   .
   # ACcess: Right IJ CVL, Right radial arterial line
   .
   # CODE: full, discussed with family
   .
   # COMM: with patient and family. Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 4273**] is HCP ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 4276**], Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4277**].
   .
   # DISP: ICU care

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old man with a complex medical history, including type 2 diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and tracheobronchomalacia with recent tracheal stenting. He presents with respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, and renal insufficiency.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to his underlying pulmonary issues, including sleep apnea, tracheobronchomalacia, and recurrent pneumonias. The risk of respiratory failure increases with the patient's altered mental status, which may exacerbate hypoventilation.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is likely related to his underlying cardiac condition, including atrial fibrillation. The risk of recurrent cardiac arrest increases if the patient's cardiac condition is not properly managed.
3. Renal insufficiency: The patient's renal insufficiency is likely due to his underlying kidney disease and the use of nephrotoxic medications. The risk of worsening renal insufficiency increases if the patient's blood pressure is not properly controlled.
4. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is likely due to his underlying diabetes and the use of steroids. The risk of hyperglycemia increases if the patient's blood sugar levels are not properly controlled.
5. Infection: The patient's underlying respiratory and cardiac conditions increase his risk of developing an infection, which can worsen his respiratory and cardiac status.
6. Sepsis: The patient's underlying infection and respiratory and cardiac conditions increase his risk of developing sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents increases his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which can worsen his respiratory and cardiac status.
8. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's underlying pulmonary conditions increase his risk of developing a pulmonary embolism, which can worsen his respiratory status.

Based on the patient's condition and medical history, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies to detect any potential complications early and intervene promptly to prevent worsening of his condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old man with a complex medical history, including type 2 diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and tracheobronchomalacia with recent tracheal stenting. He presents with respiratory failure, likely exacerbated by sleep apnea, tracheobronchomalacia, and recurrent pneumonias. He also has a history of cardiac arrest, which may be related to hypercarbia and hypoxia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is extubated and on a face tent with a SpO2 of 93%. His ABG shows a pH of 7.35, PaCO2 of 57, and PaO2 of 338.
* Cardiac status: The patient has a pacer working normally, but not firing on top of QRS. His cardiac rhythm is atrial sense with ventricular pacing.
* Renal status: The patient has renal insufficiency, with a baseline creatinine of 0.9-1.1 mg/dL. His creatinine is currently 1.2 mg/dL, which is improving with IV fluids and resuscitation.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient's blood pressure is 137/59 mmHg, and his central venous pressure is 11 mmHg.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require further respiratory support.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's pacer is not firing on top of QRS, which may indicate a potential for cardiac arrhythmias.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal insufficiency may worsen if he continues to experience hypotension or if his creatinine levels do not improve.
* Sepsis: The patient has a history of recurrent pneumonias and is currently receiving antibiotics for a suspected HCAP. He may be at risk for developing sepsis.
* Neurologic deficits: The patient's altered mental status may be related to his underlying medical conditions, and he may be at risk for developing neurologic deficits.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Adjusting ventilator settings based on ABGs
* Monitoring blood sugar levels and adjusting insulin therapy as needed
* Continuing to monitor blood pressure and adjusting medications as needed
* Treating HCAP with cefepime and vancomycin
* Sending sputum culture and repeating lactate levels
* Cycling CK levels to peak and performing an EKG in the morning
* Continuing to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjusting therapy as needed.

   shock and arrest, already improving with IVF and resuscitation. Now

   family history, patient will fall asleep frequently during the day.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old male who presented with a status post PEA arrest and was admitted to the ICU. The patient has a complex medical history, including type 2 DM, AVR x2, and TBM s/p tracheal stenting.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient was intubated and on mechanical ventilation, but was extubated on the current day. He remains somnolent and hypercarbic, with an SpO2 of 93%. His respiratory support includes a face tent with CPAP/PSV mode, with a FiO2 of 50%.
* Cardiac status: The patient's cardiac status is unclear, as the circumstances surrounding the arrest are unknown. He has a pacemaker that is working normally, producing almost every ventricular beat, but not firing on top of QRS.
* Renal status: The patient's creatinine level has resolved, and he is no longer in renal insufficiency.
* Neurological status: The patient's mental status is improving, but he remains slow to respond.
* Diabetes management: The patient's blood sugar levels were in the 300s on arrival to the ICU, and he was started on insulin and monitoring q1h. He is now on Lantus and will start on his home regimen when he is eating.
* Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is stabilized, and he is restarting his home antihypertensive regimen.
* Hypercholesterolemia: The patient will be reinitiated on a statin when he is taking POs.
* Chronic pain: The patient's pain is being continually reassessed, and he is not complaining of significant pain.
* CK elevation: The patient's CK level is trending down and is unlikely to be cardiac in origin.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still concerning, with ongoing hypercarbia and potential for further respiratory decline.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is unclear, and he may be at risk for further cardiac events, including arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
* Neurological complications: The patient's mental status is improving, but he may still be at risk for further neurological decline or deficits.
* Renal complications: The patient's creatinine level has resolved, but he may still be at risk for further renal dysfunction or injury.
* Infection: The patient's sputum cultures show a mixed flora, including GNR, GPR, and Gram-positive cocci, which may indicate a potential infection.
* Bleeding: The patient's INR is 1.3, which may indicate a risk for bleeding.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a history of hypertension, type II diabetes, altered mental status, and cardiac arrest. They were intubated and placed on invasive ventilation, which was discontinued 11 hours after admission. The patient has been receiving antibiotics, including cefipime and vancomycin, and has been managed with various medications, including pantoprazole, metoprolol, and hydralazine.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 72 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 137/59 mmHg. They are receiving oxygen therapy and have a SpO2 of 93%. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute and a tidal volume of 359 mL.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 14.7, hemoglobin of 12.1 g/dL, and platelet count of 213 K/uL. Their electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with a potassium level of 4.2 mEq/L and a sodium level of 143 mEq/L. The patient's troponin level is 0.07 ng/mL, and their creatinine level is 0.9 mg/dL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but they may still be at risk for respiratory failure due to their underlying medical conditions.
2. Sepsis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and they are receiving antibiotics, which may indicate the presence of sepsis.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac arrest history and ongoing cardiac monitoring may indicate a risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
4. Infection: The patient's altered mental status and respiratory failure may indicate the presence of an underlying infection.
5. Metabolic complications: The patient's diabetes and electrolyte imbalances may indicate a risk for metabolic complications, such as hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.
6. Bleeding complications: The patient's platelet count is elevated, which may indicate a risk for bleeding complications.
7. DVT: The patient is at risk for DVT due to their prolonged immobility and medical conditions.
8. VAP: The patient is at risk for VAP due to their intubation and prolonged ventilation.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 66 y/o man with PMH notable for type 2 DM, AVR X 2, and TBM
   s/p tracheal stent who presents status post PEA arrest.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Again unclear precipitant though patient has
   multiple pulmonary issues including sleep apnea (likely obesity
   hypoventilation syndrome), tracheobronchomalacia with recent tracheal
   stenting, and recurrent pneumonias (antibiotics almost continuously per
   wife due to sputum production). He also apparently takes multiple
   narcotics and other meds (i.e., flexeril, seroquel, valium) which could
   contribute to altered mental status which would exacerbate
   hypoventilation.
   - adjust ventilator settings per ABGs
 currently on PSV wean, on vent
   overnight - > diuresed overnight and this AM
 extubated on [**12-23**]
   - obtained records from [**Location (un) 755**] regarding tracheal stenting
   - send sputum culture
 if available
 Coag + SA
 cover with
   Vanc/Cefepime until [**Last Name (un) 4361**]
   - urine legionella antigen - negative
   .
   # Renal insufficiency: Unclear baseline creatinine. Would be helpful to
   obtain records from PCP or coverage over the weekend. Likely that
   creatinine will be higher in setting of shock and arrest, already
   improving with IVF and resuscitation.
   - trend creatinine
 improving as of [**12-23**]
   - adjusted meds for improved renal fxn
   - avoided nephrotoxins
   - obtained recs from [**Hospital3 3928**]
 renal fxn baseline ~ 0.9-1.1.
   .
   # Cardiac status: Unclear circumstances surrounding the arrest. From
   family history, patient will fall asleep frequently during the day.
   This could be secondary to chronic hypercarbia which could be
   exacerbated by patient's multiple narcotic pain medications. Could
   hypothesize that patient took additional narcotics which depressed his
   already-tenuous respiratory drive leading to hypercarbia and hypoxia
   which led to PEA arrest. Other possibility is cardiac event but ekg on
   admit not necessarily concerning for MI. Other etiologies (electrolyte
   abnormalities, PE, hypothermia) less likely given lab and scan results.
   Unclear what type of neurologic deficits, if any, he will have
   following this event. We elected not to cool him per protocol with
   arctic sun due to length of time since arrest (~ 1315 and 1815 on
   arrival to MICU) in addition to instability of blood pressures (on 3
   pressors on arrival to MICU).
   - off pressors
   - overnight and this AM pt had continuous firing of pacer
 EP will
   re-eval [**12-23**]
   - support respiratory failure
 now extubated on face tent
   - enzymes cycled
 no issues remain
   - reassess neurologic status now that pt is extubated
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus: FSBS in 300s on arrival to the ICU. Will start
   insulin gtt and monitor blood sugars q1h until under better control.
 advanced Lantus to 20 [**Hospital1 7**], will start on home regimen when back to
   eating will follow FSBGs
   .
   # Hypertension: Hold antihypertensives for now given pressor
   requirement on arrival. Reconsider initiation of meds when stabilized,
   though home regimen unclear.  Stabilized started BP medications
   - started correction to previous note - started Metoprolol and Hydral
   [**12-20**]
   - once PO plan is to restart home meds
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia: Reinitiate statin when NG in place or patient
   taking POs.
   .
   # Chronic pain: Will continually reassess. D/c
d sedation and will wait
   for mental status to improve prior to giving any narcotics or benzos,
   etc.
   .
   . # Shock: Patient's hypotension on arrival to [**Hospital1 19**] could be related
   to profound acidosis in setting of resuscitation or hypothermia.
   Following aggressive IVFs in ED, pressors were quickly weaned to off on
   arrival to the ICU. Could also be [**2-8**] to underlying infectious source
   (did have leukocytosis and bandemia on arrival) and most obvious source
   is infiltrates seen on chest CT. UA negative on arrival. Cardiac
   function (per echo performed in the ED) preserved at this time so less
   suspicion for cardiac shock. Resolved
   - continue to monitor blood pressure with arterial line
   - treat broadly for HCAP with cefepime / vancomycin
   - send sputum culture
   - repeat lactate
   - pressures stable
   .
   # CK elevation: Unlikely cardiac source given low MB and MBI. Troponin
   slightly elevated but in setting of renal insufficiency and stress from
   hypotension.  Resolved
   - cycle CKs to peak
   - EKG in AM
   .
   # FEN: npo for now as no NG, replete lytes prn
   .
   # PPx: ppi, bowel meds, pneumoboots for now
   .

   .

Based on the provided daily progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 66-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and tracheobronchomalacia, who presented with respiratory failure and cardiac arrest. He was found to have multiple pulmonary issues, including sleep apnea, tracheobronchomalacia, and recurrent pneumonias, which may have contributed to his respiratory failure. He also has a history of taking multiple medications, including narcotics, which may have exacerbated his respiratory depression.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 14.7
* Hct: 30.9
* Plt: 213
* Cr: 1.2
* TropT: 0.07
* TCO2: 30
* Glucose: 142
* Lactic Acid: 1.2 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.5 g/dL
* LDH: 224 IU/L
* Ca++: 8.5 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.2 mg/dL
* PO4: 3.1 mg/dL

The patient's vital signs are:

* Tmax: 36.9 C (98.5 F)
* Tcurrent: 36 C (96.8 F)
* HR: 72 (72-89) bpm
* BP: 137/59 (82) mmHg
* RR: 23 (18-27) inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 93%
* Heart rhythm: V paced

The patient's physical examination is:

* Peripheral Vascular: Not assessed
* Skin: Not assessed
* Neurologic: Responds to stimuli, movement, and tone not assessed

The patient's medical plan includes:

* Adjusting ventilator settings based on ABGs
* Weaning from pressors
* Reassessing neurologic status
* Monitoring blood sugar levels
* Initiating insulin drip and monitoring blood sugars q1h
* Holding antihypertensives for now and restarting when stabilized
* Reinitiating statin when NG in place or patient taking POs
* Continually reassessing chronic pain
* Monitoring blood pressure with arterial line
* Treating broadly for HCAP with cefepime/vancomycin
* Sending sputum culture
* Repeating lactate
* Cycling CKs to peak
* EKG in AM

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not adequately managed.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac arrest may lead to cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac tamponade.
* Renal insufficiency: The patient's renal insufficiency may worsen if not adequately managed.
* Sepsis: The patient's infection may lead to sepsis, which can be life-threatening.
* Hypoglycemia: The patient's diabetes may lead to hypoglycemia, which can be life-threatening.
* Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may worsen if not adequately managed.
* Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium levels may become elevated, which can be life-threatening.

Based on the patient's condition and laboratory results, I recommend that the patient continue to receive close monitoring and treatment in the ICU.

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health status and potential medical complications:

**Current Status:**

* The patient is a 24-hour survivor of cardiac arrest and is currently in the ICU.
* Vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 72 bpm, and blood pressure of 165/78 mmHg.
* The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy via nasal cannula.
* Laboratory results show mild anemia, elevated white blood cell count, and normal liver function.
* The patient has a history of hypertension, type II diabetes, and altered mental status.

**Potential Complications:**

1. **Cardiac Complications:** The patient's cardiac arrest and history of hypertension and type II diabetes make them susceptible to cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and myocardial infarction.
2. **Respiratory Complications:** The patient's acute respiratory failure and requirement for mechanical ventilation increase the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), respiratory distress syndrome, and acute lung injury.
3. **Infection:** The patient's altered mental status and respiratory failure increase the risk of nosocomial infections, particularly VAP.
4. **Gastrointestinal Complications:** The patient's history of diabetes and hypertension increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding, pancreatitis, and small bowel obstruction.
5. **Renal Complications:** The patient's history of hypertension and diabetes increase the risk of acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease.
6. **Neurological Complications:** The patient's altered mental status and history of diabetes and hypertension increase the risk of neurological complications such as stroke, seizures, and cognitive impairment.
7. **Hemodynamic Instability:** The patient's history of cardiac arrest and hypertension increase the risk of hemodynamic instability, including hypotension and hypertension.

**Recommendations:**

1. Monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and hemodynamic status closely.
2. Continue to optimize the patient's respiratory status and consider weaning from mechanical ventilation.
3. Implement measures to prevent VAP, including elevating the head of the bed, using a VAP-reducing ventilation strategy, and administering antibiotics as indicated.
4. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels closely and adjust insulin therapy as necessary.
5. Consider consulting a cardiologist to optimize the patient's cardiac care.
6. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and consider consulting a nephrologist if necessary.
7. Consider consulting a neurologist to optimize the patient's neurological care.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 66 y/o man with PMH notable for type 2 DM, AVR X 2, and TBM
   s/p tracheal stent who presents status post PEA arrest.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Resolving. Again unclear precipitant though
   patient has multiple pulmonary issues including sleep apnea (likely
   obesity hypoventilation syndrome), tracheobronchomalacia with recent
   tracheal stenting, and recurrent pneumonias (antibiotics almost
   continuously per wife due to sputum production). He also apparently
   takes multiple narcotics and other meds (i.e., flexeril, seroquel,
   valium) which could contribute to altered mental status which would
   exacerbate hypoventilation.
   - extubated on [**12-23**]
   - obtained records from [**Location (un) 755**] regarding tracheal stenting
   -Coag + SA
 cover with Vanc, awaiting sensitivities
   - [**12-23**] sputum with multiple back on GS. Concerning given treatment
   with cefepime. However prelim growth of only OP flora, likely just
   colonizer. Therefore have not changed abx. If spikes or clinically
   worsens add meropenem for possible ESBL or pseudomonas. Still coughing
   up large amount green sputum
   - urine legionella antigen - negative
   .
   # Renal insufficiency: Resolved. baseline creatinine 0.9 to 1.1 per
   [**Hospital3 3928**]. Likely that creatinine will be higher in setting of
   shock and arrest, already improving with IVF and resuscitation. Now
   returned to [**Location 810**] range
   - trend creatinine
   - avoided nephrotoxins
   .
   # Cardiac status: Unclear circumstances surrounding the arrest. From
   family history, patient will fall asleep frequently during the day.
   This could be secondary to chronic hypercarbia which could be
   exacerbated by patient's multiple narcotic pain medications. Could
   hypothesize that patient took additional narcotics which depressed his
   already-tenuous respiratory drive leading to hypercarbia and hypoxia
   which led to PEA arrest. Other possibility is cardiac event but ekg on
   admit, not concerning for MI. Other etiologies (electrolyte
   abnormalities, PE, hypothermia) less likely given lab and scan results.
   Unclear what type of neurologic deficits, if any, he will have
   following this event. We elected not to cool him per protocol with
   arctic sun due to length of time since arrest (~ 1315 and 1815 on
   arrival to MICU) in addition to instability of blood pressures (on 3
   pressors on arrival to MICU).
   - off pressors
   - overnight and this AM pt had continuous firing of pacer
   re-evaled [**12-23**] shortened a sensing interval
   - support respiratory failure
 now extubated on face tent
   - enzymes cycled
 no issues remain
   - reassess neurologic status now that pt is extubated
   -repeat echo, EF greater than 55 %, high transaoritc valve pressure
   gradiant. Largely unchanged since echo on presentation
   .
   # mental status: question of anoxic injury after down so long in field.
   Pt improving but remains slow to respond
   -trend MS
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus: FSBS in 300s on arrival to the ICU. Was on
   insulin gtt and monitor blood sugars q1h until under better control.
 advanced Lantus to 20 [**Hospital1 7**], will start on home regimen when back to
   eating will follow FSBGs
   .
   # Hypertension:Held antihypertensives on arrival w given pressor
   requirement. Now stabilized, restarting home reg
   - started Metoprolol and Hydral [**12-20**]
   - Restarted ACE as trial for swallowing Pills. If tolerates convert to
   previous oral BP reg
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia: Reinitiate statin when clear patient taking
   POs.
   .
   # Chronic pain: Will continually reassess. D/c
d sedation and will wait
   for mental status to improve prior to giving any narcotics or benzos,
   etc. Not complaining of significant pain.
   ..
   # CK elevation: Unlikely cardiac source given low MB and MBI. Troponin
   slightly elevated but in setting of renal insufficiency and stress from
   hypotension.  Resolved
   -continuing to downtrend
   .
   # FEN: attempting pills with applesauce, advance diet if tolearating
   pills well, replete lytes prn
   .
   # PPx: ppi, bowel meds, pneumoboots for now
   .
   # ACcess: Right IJ CVL, Right radial arterial line . Requesting PICC,

Summary:

The patient is a 66-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes, atrial valve replacement, and tracheobronchomalacia with recent tracheal stenting. He presents with respiratory failure, renal insufficiency, cardiac arrest, and altered mental status. He was found to have a prolonged QT interval, and his electrocardiogram (ECG) showed a possible atrial fibrillation. He was given antibiotics for a suspected pneumonia, and his creatinine level was trending down. He was also given diuretics for fluid overload.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and he is at risk for further respiratory failure, especially with his tracheobronchomalacia and recurrent pneumonias.
2. Renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine level is still elevated, and he is at risk for further kidney damage if not properly managed.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is still unexplained, and he is at risk for further cardiac events if not properly managed.
4. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is still unclear, and he is at risk for further cognitive decline if not properly managed.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose level is still elevated, and he is at risk for further hyperglycemic episodes if not properly managed.
6. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is still elevated, and he is at risk for further hypertensive episodes if not properly managed.
7. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient's cholesterol level is still elevated, and he is at risk for further cardiovascular events if not properly managed.
8. Chronic pain: The patient's chronic pain is still unmanaged, and he is at risk for further pain episodes if not properly managed.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is still unstable, and he requires close monitoring and management. The plan is to continue to manage his respiratory failure, renal insufficiency, cardiac arrest, and altered mental status. The patient will also require further management of his hyperglycemia, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and chronic pain.

The patient has multiple potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has a history of sleep apnea, tracheobronchomalacia, and recurrent pneumonias, which can contribute to respiratory failure. His current respiratory status is improving, but he is still at risk for further respiratory complications.
2. Renal insufficiency: The patient's baseline creatinine is 0.9-1.1, and he has a history of renal insufficiency. His current creatinine level is within the normal range, but he is still at risk for further renal damage due to his underlying medical conditions and medications.
3. Cardiac status: The patient's cardiac status is unclear due to the circumstances surrounding his arrest. He has a history of atrial valve replacement and may have had a cardiac event leading to his arrest. His current cardiac status is stable, but he is at risk for further cardiac complications.
4. Mental status: The patient's mental status is improving, but he is still slow to respond. He may have suffered an anoxic injury due to his prolonged period of cardiac arrest, which can lead to long-term cognitive and behavioral changes.
5. Diabetes mellitus: The patient's blood sugar levels are currently under control, but he is at risk for further hyperglycemia due to his underlying diabetes and medications.
6. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is currently stable, but he is at risk for further hypertension due to his underlying medical conditions and medications.
7. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient's cholesterol levels are currently not well-controlled, and he is at risk for further hypercholesterolemia due to his underlying medical conditions and medications.
8. Chronic pain: The patient is currently not complaining of significant pain, but he may experience chronic pain due to his underlying medical conditions and medications.
9. CK elevation: The patient's CK levels are currently resolving, but he is at risk for further muscle damage due to his underlying medical conditions and medications.
10. Feeding: The patient is currently receiving nutrition through a feeding tube, but he is at risk for further malnutrition due to his underlying medical conditions and medications.

Overall, the patient is at risk for multiple medical complications due to his complex medical history and current condition. Close monitoring and management of his underlying medical conditions and medications are necessary to prevent further complications.

   This is a 66 y/o man with PMH notable for type 2 DM, AVR X 2, and TBM

   # Respiratory failure:  Resolved. Again unclear precipitant though
   patient has multiple pulmonary issues including sleep apnea (likely
   obesity hypoventilation syndrome), tracheobronchomalacia with recent
   tracheal stenting, and recurrent pneumonias (antibiotics almost
   continuously per wife due to sputum production). He also apparently
   takes multiple narcotics and other meds (i.e., flexeril, seroquel,
   valium) which could contribute to altered mental status which would
   exacerbate hypoventilation.
   - extubated on [**12-23**], sating well on 4L
   - obtained records from [**Location (un) 755**] regarding tracheal stenting
   -Coag + SA
 cover with Vanc, awaiting sensitivities
   - [**12-23**] sputum with multiple bacteria on GS. Concerning given treatment
   with cefepime. However prelim growth of only OP flora, likely just
   colonizer. Therefore have not changed abx. If spikes or clinically
   worsens add meropenem for possible ESBL or pseudomonas. Sputum
   decreasing
   - urine legionella antigen
 negative
   -continue to diurese to improve resp status. Goal negative 1.5 L daily
   .
   # Renal insufficiency: Resolved. baseline creatinine 0.9 to 1.1 per
   [**Hospital3 3928**]. Likely that creatinine will be higher in setting of
   shock and arrest, already improving with IVF and resuscitation. Now
   returned to [**Location 810**] range
   - trend creatinine
   - avoided nephrotoxins
   .
   # Cardiac status: Unclear circumstances surrounding the arrest. From
   family history, patient will fall asleep frequently during the day.
   This could be secondary to chronic hypercarbia which could be
   exacerbated by patient's multiple narcotic pain medications. Could
   hypothesize that patient took additional narcotics which depressed his
   already-tenuous respiratory drive leading to hypercarbia and hypoxia
   which led to PEA arrest. Other possibility is cardiac event but ekg on
   admit, not concerning for MI. Other etiologies (electrolyte
   abnormalities, PE, hypothermia) less likely given lab and scan results.
   Unclear what type of neurologic deficits, if any, he will have
   following this event. We elected not to cool him per protocol with
   arctic sun due to length of time since arrest (~ 1315 and 1815 on
   arrival to MICU) in addition to instability of blood pressures (on 3
   pressors on arrival to MICU).
   - off pressors
